title: 111_hr3703
content:
The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Autism Act of 2009". The Congress acknowledges the rapid increase in Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) in the U.S., with rates now at 1 in 150, constituting an epidemic. The prevalence of autism continues to rise, with a new case diagnosed every 20 minutes. The financial burden of autism on the nation exceeds $35 billion annually and is expected to rise. The current support systems in education, labor, housing, and healthcare are inadequate for addressing the needs of individuals with autism. The autism epidemic in the US is a significant concern, with a lack of preparedness in education, labor, housing, and healthcare sectors. There is a potential loss of future talent in various fields due to autism. Despite being a pressing issue, autism research receives minimal federal funding compared to other childhood diseases. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 allocated nearly $1 billion for research, including studies on environmental factors and early intervention services. A White House Conference on Autism offers a chance to further advance efforts in this area. A White House Conference on Autism provides an opportunity to advance research on cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. The White House Conference on Autism is authorized. The President is required to call the White House Conference on Autism by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations on combating the autism epidemic in the US. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing and Urban Development will plan and convene the Conference to find the causes of autism, provide solutions and services for autistic individuals and families, and engage scientific experts. The White House Conference on Autism aims to address challenges faced by autistic individuals and families, conduct comprehensive research on potential triggers, facilitate a national dialogue on lifelong challenges, showcase effective programs, and review existing legislation for autism research services. The White House Conference on Autism aims to develop specific recommendations for legislative action to improve bills and programs for autism research services, enhancing the health and well-being of autistic individuals and their families. SEC. 4. POLICY COMMITTEE; RELATED COMMITTEES. Established by June 30, 2009, the Policy Committee consists of 17 members selected by the President, House appointees, and Senate appointees. The committee includes members with experience in addressing the needs of people with autism spectrum disorders in the United States. The Policy Committee, established in 2009, consists of 17 members appointed by the President, House, and Senate leaders. 50% of the members must come from private industry, the nonprofit sector, or academia, with specific qualifications including knowledge about autism intervention programs and being a parent or legal guardian of individuals with autism. The Policy Committee, established in 2009, consists of 17 members appointed by the President, House, and Senate leaders. The committee members must have specific qualifications including knowledge about autism intervention programs, education, housing, law enforcement training, and environmental factors related to autism development. The committee acts by majority vote with a quorum required for conducting business. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, meets to make recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference, propose an agenda, suggest delegates, and determine the number of delegates to be selected. Meetings are initially called by the Cochairs and subsequently by the chairperson. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, meets to make recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference, propose an agenda, suggest delegates, and establish an executive committee consisting of 3 members to work with delegates. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES.

The Cochairs will gather delegates from various backgrounds in the field of autism and neurodevelopmental disorders, including government representatives, professionals, laypeople, and members of the public affected by autism spectrum disorders in the United States.

SEC. 6. CONFERENCE ADMINISTRATION. In administering this section, the Cochairs shall provide notice of meetings to the Policy Committee, request cooperation from other Federal departments, make proposed agendas public, provide background materials to delegates, and hire additional personnel as needed. The Cochairs may hire additional personnel without following certain regulations, ensure a balanced representation of views, and prevent inappropriate influence on recommendations. The Cochairs of the Conference on autism spectrum disorders may accept gifts to support the independent judgment of delegates and ensure necessary data and information are available before the Conference. The Cochairs of the Conference on autism spectrum disorders may accept gifts to support the independent judgment of delegates and ensure necessary data and information are available before the Conference. Gifts of cash may be earmarked for specific purposes. The Cochairs will maintain records of sources, amounts, and uses of gifts, as well as the recipients of assistance and the amount received by each. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE. The Policy Committee will prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state CEOs. A final report, including state CEOs' views, will be prepared within 6 months and submitted to the President and Congress. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. The Surgeon General will prepare an initial status report within 2 years of the Conference adjournment, documenting the implementation of recommendations from the final report. Subsequent status reports will be prepared by the Comptroller General every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved. SEC. 9. DEFINITION OF STATE. The term "State" in this Act refers to several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, or the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization is granted for necessary appropriations to carry out the Act, with limitations on new spending authority. Funds appropriated or received as gifts shall remain available for one year after the Conference adjourns. Any unexpended funds from the Conference must be returned to the Treasury if not used within a year. If the Conference does not take place before December 31, 2010, a trust fund will be established for a future Conference on Autism.
